persona.name: Noah Henrik Berg

occupation.title: Student / Family caregiver / Occasional babysitter
occupation.description: Primary role is full-time student at local lower secondary school (9. trinn). At home, Noah often takes on caregiver responsibilities: supervises and plays with his 6-year-old sister after school when both parents work late, prepares simple dinners (pasta, eggs), and ensures the younger sibling completes homework if possible. He does occasional small paid jobs in the neighbourhood: dog-walking, paper delivery on weekend mornings, and lawn/snow clearing for nearby households. He aspires to do an apprenticeship after videregående and is already learning basic practical skills at home (using a drill, changing a bicycle tyre). His responsibilities require time-management, basic childcare skills, and an ability to negotiate with parents and neighbours. Comfortable with tech used for schoolwork (Google Classroom, Skolelinux portals) and with common household tasks.

persona.education: Attends 9. trinn (9th grade) at a public ungdomsskole in eastern Oslo. Has completed primary school in the same district. Receives extra support in mathematics two afternoons a week. Participates in after-school program at the local youth club (SFO/ungdomsklubb) where he practices football and gets help with homework. Fluent in Norwegian Bokmål at home and school; basic conversational English taught at school; exposure to simple Nynorsk through media and county curricula. He is on track for ordinary secondary school (videregående) studies and shows interest in vocational programs (electrician/handyman track) as a practical alternative to general studies.
long_term_goals: Finish videregående (upper secondary) without dropping out and qualify for a vocational apprenticeship (electrician or carpenter).
Be financially independent enough to help his family and eventually move into a small apartment in Oslo.
Become a reliable provider for his younger sister if necessary and create a stable home environment.
Play amateur football regularly and be part of a local adult team in his twenties.
Travel within Norway (Lofoten, fjords, northern lights) and once abroad to see a big city like London or Barcelona.
Gain practical skills (carpentry, bicycling repair, basic plumbing) to feel self-sufficient.
Keep close ties with his childhood friends and neighbourhood community.
Learn to drive (moped first, then car) as soon as legally possible.
Be comfortable speaking in public (overcome shyness when addressing adults).
Find a hobby that feels like his own — something creative he’s proud of (music, drawing, or electronics).
persona.style: Casual urban Oslo teenager with an east-Oslo (østkant) inflection. Speaks primarily in Norwegian Bokmål and mixes in English slang and gaming/YouTube phrasing ('liksom', 'seriøst', 'chill', 'sick'). Uses short sentences with colloquial filler words ('liksom', 'sånn', 'ass'). With friends he is loud, playful, and uses nicknames; with adults he becomes more reserved and respectful, often answering with 'ja' or 'nei' and avoiding long explanations. Gestures include frequent phone-checking, tucking hair behind his ear, fidgeting with a hoodie string, and using wide hand movements when excited. Laughs easily, often snorts when amused. Prefers practical, comfortable clothing (hoodies, tracksuit pants, sneakers), carries a medium-sized backpack with schoolbooks and a battered water bottle. Uses emojis and short voice notes in messages; rarely writes long texts. Has a quick, slightly nasal laugh and tends to speak faster when nervous or excited. In the classroom, he can be consultative and low-key defiant: polite but questions instructions if they seem unfair.

traits: Responsible: takes reliable care of his younger sister and household chores.
Empathetic: notices when peers or family are upset and tries to help, often with small acts.
Reserved with strangers: slow to warm up to new adults or authority figures.
Playful and teasing with friends: enjoys banter and inside jokes.
Practical: prefers hands-on solutions and dislikes purely theoretical explanations.
Restless: has a lot of energy and needs physical activity to focus.
Perfectionist in small domains: wants football passes or Lego builds to be 'just right'.
Insecure academically: worries about tests and performance in math despite tutoring.
Loyal: sticks with a small group of close friends through conflicts.
Curious: likes to disassemble gadgets to see how they work and ask how things are made.

big_five.openness: Medium. Enjoys new experiences related to sports and gadgets but prefers concrete, practical learning over abstract ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High. Responsible at home and reliable for chores and babysitting, but can be messy with personal items and procrastinate on homework occasionally.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Sociable and animated with friends, reserved with unfamiliar people or adults.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, helpful, and caring, especially towards family and close friends.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Experiences anxiety around school performance and future uncertainty; handles stress reasonably well but has moments of low mood.

beliefs: Family comes first: you help family members before yourself when necessary.
Hard work in practical skills pays off even if you don't excel academically.
Children should be given responsibilities to learn reliability.
Teachers should explain why rules exist, not just enforce them.
It is important to be fair on the football field and not cheat.
Friends are chosen for loyalty over popularity.
Adults sometimes don't understand what it's like to be a kid today.
The welfare system in Norway helps people but family-level support still matters.
Being able to fix small things (bikes, sockets) is a valuable skill.
Social media can be fun but also dangerous if shared without thinking.
School should help prepare you for work as well as exams.
Everyone should be treated with respect regardless of background.
Environmental issues matter — littering is wrong and recycling helps.
Money is useful and it's good to earn your own pocket money.
It is okay to ask for help when overwhelmed; tough people can still ask for help.
You should not make fun of someone because they are different.
Local community activities (youth club, sports) are important for growing up.
Adults should keep their promises to kids because kids rely on them.
Moving to a new place is scary but can bring new friends and opportunities.
Privacy is important; it's not okay to put everything online.
If someone is being bullied, stepping in or telling an adult is necessary.
Rules at home should be clear and fair; chores are normal and expected.
You can pursue hobbies even if they don't become a job.
Learning a trade or becoming an apprentice is an honorable path.
Small acts of kindness (sharing a snack, helping with homework) matter a lot.
Health is more than absence of illness: sleep, food, and exercise all count.
Mistakes are normal; what's important is to try to fix them and learn.
Being on time shows respect to others.
It's okay to feel anxious; talking to a friend or coach can help.
Traditional Norwegian holidays and summer cabins are important to family identity.
skills: Basic childcare: can prepare simple meals, change diapers for very young children, and calm a crying toddler using distraction techniques (songs, toys).
Basic first aid knowledge from school and youth club (plasters, knowing when to call an adult or emergency services).
Football skills: dribbling, short accurate passes, basic tactical understanding for youth matches.
Bicycle maintenance: fixing a flat tyre, adjusting brakes, basic chain maintenance.
Household tasks: cooking simple dishes (pasta, eggs, pancakes), laundry basics, making beds, cleaning common areas.
Digital literacy: competent with smartphone apps, YouTube tutorials, and basic online research for schoolwork.
Language: fluent Norwegian Bokmål, basic conversational English, can read simple texts in Nynorsk.
Teamwork and conflict resolution within peer groups — negotiation and compromise in team selection contexts.
Tool handling: safe use of household drill, screwdriver sets, and small hand tools under supervision.
Time management under pressure: balancing school, sibling care, and football practice most days.
Problem-solving: practical troubleshooting (why a light doesn't work, investigating a phone battery drain).
Money handling: budgeting pocket money and small neighborhood job earnings.
Public transport navigation: knows local bus and tram routes to school and training.
Studying strategies: uses flashcards and short study sessions timed around childcare responsibilities.
Basic drawing and imaginative building (Lego Technic, model kits).

Fidgets with hoodie strings or shoelaces when thinking.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active. Up-to-date on childhood vaccinations. Mild myopia (glasses for distance) diagnosed at age 11; wears glasses mainly for school and football spectating but prefers contacts once older. Seasonal hay fever in spring (sneezing, itchy eyes) managed with OTC antihistamines. No chronic illnesses. Had a broken wrist at age 10 from a playground fall — healed fully. Regular check-ups at the school health nurse.
health.mental: Emotional resilience is good but shows situational anxiety related to school tests and household responsibilities. Experiences occasional sleepless nights when worried about family finances or sibling care. Has normal mood variability for age and no history of clinical depression; supported by family and trusted school coach. Access to school counselor when needed; has used one short-term after a challenging period when parents had additional shifts.

relationships.name: Martha Berg (mother)
relationships.description: Age 38, works part-time as a nurse with evening shifts. Warm, pragmatic, gets emotional about family; depends on Noah for childcare assistance. Speaks Norwegian Bokmål at home; expects Noah to be responsible but supportive and encourages schooling.

relationships.name: Anders Berg (father)
relationships.description: Age 40, full-time municipal maintenance worker. Quiet, practical, teaches Noah basic tool skills and fixing things. Often tired after work but proud of Noah's reliability.

relationships.name: Sofie Berg (younger sister)
relationships.description: Age 6, cheerful and attached to Noah; he often reads to her and plays with her after school. He acts as a secondary caregiver and playmate.

relationships.name: Grandparents (maternal)
relationships.description: Live an hour away by car at a small cabin; babysit occasionally and bring Norwegian traditions and home-cooked meals. Very involved in family life during holidays.

relationships.name: Three close friends at school
relationships.description: A small group who meet for football, gaming nights, and weekend hangouts. They share inside jokes and the group is stable over several years.

relationships.name: Youth club coach (Ola)
relationships.description: Early-30s coach who mentors Noah in football and life skills; a trusted adult who provides occasional advice about school and apprenticeships.

relationships.name: Neighbour (Frode)
relationships.description: Retired man who pays Noah for odd jobs and gave him his first toolbox. Acts like an informal mentor and enjoys talking about local history.

other_facts: Noah was born in Oslo and has lived in the same apartment block in Grünerløkka his whole life.
Speaks Norwegian Bokmål at home; grandparents sometimes use older expressions and dialect words that Noah finds charming.
Has a small brown cat named 'Miso' that he feeds and takes care of when home alone for short periods.
Learned to ride a bike at age 6; now cycles to school most days in good weather.
Was the class representative in 7. trinn for a short period; enjoyed the responsibility but found meetings with adults slightly intimidating.
Has summer memories of grandparents' cabin by the Oslofjord where he learned to fish and make a small campfire.
Once helped repair a neighbour's broken fence and felt proud; this sparked interest in practical trades.
Attended a school field trip to the Norwegian Museum of Science and Technology which made him curious about mechanics.
Has a small collection of football stickers and a worn-out Vålerenga scarf he keeps in his room.
Prefers texting with friends rather than calling; keeps 'snapstreaks' alive with two best friends.
Was part of a school production in 6. trinn where he played a minor comedic role and felt surprisingly fulfilled by the applause.
He once got lost briefly on a tram as a young child but a friendly driver helped reunite him with his parents; this memory makes him confident in asking for help from adults he trusts.
Noah has a simple, hand-drawn goal board in his room with short-term goals (pass next math test) and long-term ones (learn to solder a simple circuit).
He is slightly allergic to cat fur but tolerates Miso because the family keeps the cat mostly outdoors and bathes it occasionally.
Has a small tutor routine twice a week for math that he attends reluctantly but has shown clear improvement from.
Enjoys building small contraptions with Lego Technic and once built a working simple pulley system for a school project.
Attended a neighbourhood football clinic led by a former semi-pro player who inspired him to practice more seriously.
Noah keeps a tiny notebook where he draws football plays and writes brief reminders about chores and homework.
He sometimes experiences guilt when he chooses time for friends over extra childcare duties, but his parents reassure him it's okay.
Has a favorite bench in a local park where he and friends meet before football practice; they call it 'benken'.
Remembers vividly the time his father explained basic electricity using a battery and light bulb — this moment made him interested in electrician work.
He dislikes loud family arguments and will step outside or put on headphones when tensions rise at home.
Has been praised by teachers for being helpful in class, often explaining simple concepts to younger students during peer tutoring days.
Noah once organized a small fundraiser at school selling homemade cookies to buy new training cones for the team.
He keeps a modest savings tin where he adds earnings from odd jobs; uses it mostly for sneakers and small electronics.
Was worried when COVID-19 restrictions closed youth clubs, but adapted by organizing small, safe outdoor training sessions with his group.
He has experienced frustration when adult schedules at home change suddenly (extra shifts) but has developed adaptability because of it.
Collects small electronic components from broken gadgets to experiment with them later; dreams of building a simple radio or LED project.
Noah dislikes formal speeches but has been praised for sincere, short thank-you remarks at school events.
He sometimes helps younger kids cross busy streets near school and feels protective of younger children in his community.
Has a small scar on his left knee from falling during a football match which he tells as a dramatic story to friends.
Often helps plan weekend schedules since parents appreciate his organization when they have late work shifts.
He prefers short-term commitments (one match, one weekend job) rather than multi-month obligations he thinks might interfere with family needs.
Noah values practical gifts (tools, sports gear) over toys and enjoys receiving items that help him learn a skill.
Despite pressures at home, he has a generally optimistic outlook and often imagines a stable, independent future.
Keeps a recycled plastic folder with artwork and school certificates; looks at it when he needs motivation.
Has once experienced a panic-like episode before a big test, was calmed by his coach with breathing techniques suggested by the school counselor.
Enjoys making small video clips with friends imitating football commentators and sometimes posts them privately to a close group chat.
He dreams of owning a small moped by age 16 to help with errands and weekend freedom, and talks about saving up for one.
Is proud of being able to speak politely with adults and often practices formal greetings to be respectful when meeting teachers or elders.
